professor.name: Dr. Gupta
professor.text: This week we examine urban development. Some cities create car-free downtown zones to reduce pollution and encourage walking, while critics argue this limits access and hurts local businesses. Do you support this policy? Explain your position.

students.name: Yuki
students.text: I support car-free zones because they improve air quality and make shopping streets safer. In my hometown, weekend pedestrian zones actually increased foot traffic.

students.name: Carlos
students.text: A full ban is too strict. Cities should improve public transit first and allow limited car access for seniors and deliveries.

professor.name: Dr. Chen
professor.text: Some universities require one computer science course for all majors. Supporters call coding a basic literacy, while opponents say it crowds out discipline-specific learning. What is your view?

students.name: Aisha
students.text: A basic coding class helps students in many fields, especially where data is involved. Even one course can improve problem-solving habits.

students.name: Marco
students.text: Making it mandatory adds pressure to already full schedules. Optional pathways would be fairer for majors with little technical focus.

professor.name: Dr. Patel
professor.text: Should universities expand online course options permanently, or prioritize in-person instruction after emergency remote-learning years? Take a clear position and justify it.

students.name: Lena
students.text: Online courses make education more flexible for commuters and working students. Recorded lectures also help review difficult concepts.

students.name: James
students.text: In-person classes build stronger discussion and accountability. Group learning and spontaneous questions are harder online.

professor.name: Dr. Williams
professor.text: Many students get news primarily from social media feeds. Should media literacy become a required university course, or should departments integrate it within existing classes?

students.name: Sofia
students.text: A required course is necessary because misinformation spreads fast. Students need explicit training to verify sources and detect bias.

students.name: Ryan
students.text: Critical evaluation should be taught across subjects instead of adding another requirement. Integration avoids overloading degree plans.

professor.name: Dr. Nakamura
professor.text: Some employers are testing a four-day work week. Do you think universities should prepare students for this model by redesigning internship and project schedules? Why or why not?

students.name: Emma
students.text: Yes. If work structures are changing, students should practice time management in shorter, focused schedules before graduation.

students.name: David
students.text: Not yet. Many industries still run traditional schedules, so universities should teach adaptable planning rather than one model.

professor.name: Dr. Okafor
professor.text: Public universities are debating whether first-year students should be guaranteed on-campus housing. Evaluate whether this policy improves equity and learning outcomes.

students.name: Priya
students.text: Guaranteed housing helps new students build support networks and reduce commuting stress during the transition year.

students.name: Tom
students.text: It sounds fair, but housing shortages and costs could make this policy difficult. Financial aid and transit support might help more students.

professor.name: Dr. Kim
professor.text: Should participation grades be part of large lecture courses, or should grades rely only on exams and assignments? Provide your recommendation with reasons.

students.name: Mei
students.text: Participation should count, because it rewards preparation and encourages students to engage with ideas during class.

students.name: Alex
students.text: Participation is often subjective. Exams and written work are more consistent and less dependent on personality differences.

professor.name: Dr. Santos
professor.text: Many instructors are deciding whether AI writing tools should be permitted in draft stages. Should universities allow guided use, or ban these tools in writing courses?

students.name: Hannah
students.text: Guided use is more realistic. Students can use AI for brainstorming if instructors require transparent citation and revision logs.

students.name: Kevin
students.text: Bans are clearer and easier to enforce. Otherwise, it becomes hard to distinguish student skill from tool-generated content.

professor.name: Dr. Rivera
professor.text: Our faculty committee is considering whether internship experience should be mandatory for graduation in applied majors. What policy would you recommend?

students.name: Nora
students.text: Mandatory internships improve career readiness and help students test whether their chosen field is a good fit.

students.name: Leo
students.text: A strict requirement can disadvantage students with caregiving or financial constraints. Equivalent project options should be accepted.

professor.name: Dr. Almeida
professor.text: Should universities replace most printed textbooks with digital-only materials to lower costs, or keep both formats available? Defend one approach.

students.name: Mina
students.text: Digital materials reduce cost and update quickly. They also improve access for students who rely on searchable text tools.

students.name: Owen
students.text: Printed options are still important for focus and accessibility. A mixed model avoids forcing one learning style on everyone.

professor.name: Dr. Ibrahim
professor.text: A proposal suggests capping enrollment in writing-intensive courses at 20 students. Should universities adopt this even if it reduces scheduling flexibility?

students.name: Sara
students.text: Smaller classes improve feedback quality, which is essential in writing courses where revision guidance matters.

students.name: Daniel
students.text: Caps improve quality but can delay graduation if required classes fill quickly. Staffing plans should come first.

professor.name: Dr. Bennett
professor.text: Some departments want every student to complete one service-learning course tied to a local community project. Should this be required?

students.name: Ivy
students.text: Service-learning connects theory to real needs and helps students develop practical communication and teamwork skills.

students.name: Noah
students.text: It can be valuable, but mandatory service may conflict with work and family obligations. Flexible alternatives should be offered.
